You are saying live views are the only ones really that matter, which is false. Most commercials are are sold based on C3 or C7 ratings, not Live ratings. So if you watch the show on DVR (within the appropriate time) and don't skip the commercials, that is the same as watching it live when it comes to contributing to the ratings that matter (which is why it *does* matter if you skip commercials when playing from DVR).
All the DC shows on the CW, but not every show on the CW.

Anything viewed on a delay gets tallied in the +1 or +3 category. It doesn't matter if you actually skip commercials or not.
Incorrect.
Most commercials are sold based on C3 or C7 ratings; that is, viewers who watched the commercials within 3 or 7 days of the original airdate. These are different from the Live+3 and Live+7 ratings, which count all viewers of the show regardless of whether they watched the commercials (and are thus largely irrelevant). C3 and C7 numbers are just rarely released to the public so we don't typically see them (although AdAge will occasionally put out articles with them; [example](http://adage.com/article/media/good-news/306346/)).

Not every episode uses the same exact budget
Because they can borrow from one episode's budget to increase another's (hence bottle episode), but the total season budget will still be the per-episode budget times the number of episodes. So like when the CW ordered 4 more episodes this season they paid for four more episodes, they didn't make the producers stretch the original season's budget to cover 4 more episodes. Also remember that broadcast shows make their money primarily on a per-episode basis.

I mean that it made no sense (on multiple levels) for the purpose of Flashpoint to have been moving Supergirl to Earth-1.
From the logistical side of things: the decision for the Flash to do Flashpoint happened long before CBS dropped Supergirl and it was picked up by the CW. Neither Flash nor Supergirl would have written their season endings with the network change in mind.
From the story side of things: Flashpoint is entirely a Flash story. Yes other characters show up, but they only ones with any continuity are Barry and Eobard. The story is entirely about their actions, and at the end of things the alternate timeline gets erased and only Barry knows about it. So it would have made absolutely no sense for any show other than The Flash to have spent any time in Flashpoint or be significantly affected by it.
Furthermore the 'universe merging' aspect of Flashpoint is almost completely irrelevant to the main storyline of Flashpoint, and was the result of outside forces (later revealed to be Doctor Manhattan) not Barry's actions. So there's little reason to think the TV take on Flashpoint would necessarily include that at all.
Lastly, Supergirl had its own storylines including a cliffhanger coming into this season (which again was set up prior to the network change). It would have made no sense to ignore those for the sake a story from a different show; opening Supergirl S2 with Flashpoint would have been a great way to completely tank its transition to the CW.
You know, just because some doesn't like the Alex and Maggie relationship *doesn't mean they necessarily like the Kara and Mon-El relationship*. Stop framing everything as a shipper war.

If I was invested in that fund during that time it seems like I'd still be getting a dividend every month and since I am not selling the fund it isn't clear to me how my return would be negative.
The fund has a value at all times, even if you don't sell it. Your return is the change in value of the fund plus the payouts you've received from it, so if the value of the fund goes down then your return can be negative.
Also you can replace "fund" with "bond" in the preceding paragraph and nothing changes.

If that's the case why even worry about fluctuating rates or prices or anything if you just buy and hold till it matures.
Because your holdings don't exist in a vacuum. If you buy a ten year bond at 2% and then the rate jumps to 3%, you've effectively lost money by not waiting and buying at the higher rate and the resale value of your bond will drop accordingly. Saying that the current value of your bond doesn't matter because I'm holding it to maturity doesn't negate that opportunity cost, it only means you're ignoring it. And in real terms you can still lose money holding a bond to maturity if inflation rises high enough (and bond rates tend to be related to interest rates).
do you focus on PRICE or do you focus on YIELD?
Why must your focus be a binary choice between these?
Really what you seem to be asking is "why buy a bond fund with constant maturity rather than buy individual bonds and hold them to maturity?", and there are many reasons for doing that.

Bond funds are just a bunch of bonds, the value of which is determined exactly the same way as the value of an individual bond. Bond funds have interest rate risk because individual bonds have interest rate risk.
Now holding a bond fund that maintains an average maturity of 10 years is not the same as buying a ten year bond and holding it for ten years, because a ten year bond does not stay a ten year bond for its lifetime (after a year it becomes a 9 year bond, and so on). So you shouldn't expect the same performance between those two scenarios, because they're not equivalent. However as /u/fakerfakefakerson pointed out, there are bond funds that maintain a fixed maturity date and thus perform comparably to holding a single bond to maturity.

If you're matching known future liabilities then it can make more sense to use individual bonds than bond funds, but mostly because it may be more convenient rather than because interest rate risk is somehow mitigated by only holding individual bonds.You could get pretty much the same result from bond funds; bond funds typically maintain a pretty constant average maturity while an individual bond doesn't, but you can just adjust your fund allocations so that the average maturity of your bond holdings goes down over time like a single bond would.
And if you're not matching specific liabilities then your point is moot.
The DEO has known her identity since she first arrived on Earth, it was never a secret.

Point 2 seems to be mitigated if you simply just hold the bond to maturity.
This isn't mitigating interest rate risk, it's just ignoring it.

OP should care; investing in a specific company without any regard for its valuation is moronic.

Constantine *was* a live-action show, but it was cancelled two years ago. It is now an animated show on CW Seed just like Vixen and The Ray.
iZombie and Lucifer are produced by DC and WBTV; Preacher is not. So depending on how we're defining "DC Television" it could make sense to include iZombie and Lucifer but not Preacher.
Black Lighting will probably get picked up (though their choice of costume designer says nothing about it's chances), but as of now it has not. If/when it is officially picked up it should then be immediately added to the sidebar at that time.

The sidebar appears to only have live-action shows, so Constantine's absence is in line with that. If Constantine get added then Vixen and The Ray should also be added.
Preacher, despite the comics being published under DC's Vertigo imprint, does not appear to be owned by DC and neither DC nor WB is involved in the production of the show, so it's debatable whether it should be included in a 'DC Television' list.
Black Lightning has not been ordered to series. Krypton and Scalped are other DC shows that are currently in the pilot stage.
